results.title: Our golden heritage
results.creator_credit: Film Partnership (Vic.) and Australian Dairy Board
results.brief_description: Traces the early methods of making butter, capturing something of the simplicity of Australia’s early history. From here the scene moves to the modern interior of a dairy factory showing buttermakers and packers at work. To conclude, some examples of the ways butter can be used in cooking are shown.

results.title: Our food
results.brief_description: Traces the sources and processing of many familiar foods. Shows both the old fashioned and modern ways of raising wheat, making bread, milking cows and separating cream. Includes visits to a spaghetti factory, chicken and egg farm, a dairy, a cheese factory, a potato field, an apple orchard, a fishing trawler, a meat processing plant and a sausage shop. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Our federal constitutional system
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Building Political Leadership”.
According to Dr. Ivan Hinderaker, the founders of the United States of America questioned whether they should control it. He explains how the American Constitution and the Bill of Rights came about, and claim that there are three main classifications of government: Dictatorship or Democracy? Unitary or Federal? Parliamentary or Presidential? Good use of graphics as an educational tool.

results.title: Our feathered friends
results.creator_credit: Ezra Mir, Films Division, Government of India and Goopal Datt
results.brief_description: Fascinating birds abound in India. On the water there are storks, spoonbills, ibis, pelicans which are varied as to color, size and the shape of their beaks. Quiet except during the breeding season in contrast to others which chatter constantly, such as seagulls migrating from Europe. The monsoon heralds the mating season, when storks choose partners, court each other with dances and build nests for their young in trees or on the water in the reeds or on mounds, like the flamingoes, whose chicks change color as they grow up far from human habitation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ezra Mir, Films Division, Government of India and Goopal Datt

results.title: Our Earth
results.brief_description: A study of the physical properties of the earth in relation to population density and industries. Beginning with oceans and ocean currents and their effects on climate, and consequently on people, the film goes on to show analogous effects of various types of coastline and harbours, lakes, valleys, plateaus, plains and mountains.

results.title: Our daily bread [B&W]
results.creator_credit: Peter Whitchurch, Peter Whitchurch Productions, Kinelab and Dennis Hill Productions
results.brief_description: Opens with a brief historical survey of the origin of bread. Shows the processes involved in modern bread-making; growing of wheat, harvesting, shipping, storing, milling and baking, and explains the function of yeast in bread-making. The film also surveys the work of the Bread Research Laboratory in Sydney, established to improve efficiency and product standards.

results.title: Our crowded environment
results.brief_description: Shows problems that have resulted from the population explosion. Challenges views to conserve present resources and to apply technological discoveries to safeguard their future.

results.title: Our constitution
results.creator_credit: M. Bhavnani, Documentary Films of India and Krishna Gopal
results.brief_description: The spirit of the Indian constitution and the institutions of Indian government. The Federal and State legislatures; how they are elected; how they function; the fields in which they may legislate; the President, Prime Minister, Compotroller and Auditor-General; Union Public Service Commission and Electoral Commission; independence of the judiciary; the citizens’ rights; Indian democracy.
